9.9.17  2:19 pm   hey bill can you give me some advice? i have aspergers, and i have been discriminated A LOT for it, which totally wrecked my self esteem. trough out middle and high school i've been treated like i'm a fucking retard. so much that even I believed i was a retard. i refused to shut up about having aspergers / being autistic tho, because i want people to know who i am. when i was 21 i decided to turn things around and stop telling anyone i was autistic, and tell the people who knew / still tought i was, i told them that the diagnosis was not right. not because it wasnt right, i dont know it if it was right. but that diagnosis made people not treat me right, and refuse to listen to who i actually am because the assumed they already knew, because they had read an article about aspergers or something. so right now in my life hardly anyone knows i used to wear this label. it feels good because for once people will actually listen to who i am instead of assum e. BUT t he misconceptions about aspergers remain. even with new people in my life, some of these people still think autistic = retarded / incapable of anything except math. i feel bad because by shutting up about my diagnosis i am not helping other who still get discriminated. should i 'come out' again as having aspergers? so that people will know people with aspgergers actually all have a different personality that is build up of many layers just like everybody else?

9.9.17  9:47 am   I've been learning "Josie" on piano... For that part that goes "she's the raw flame, the live wire"... I'm hearing it as Am, D7, Gmaj7,Cmaj7... But the way it's voiced, I think is something like ACEG(raw), ACDF#(flame), GBDF#(live),to GBCE(wire). I think that's pretty nifty!

     You got those 4 chords played in succession, but with very little movement between the voicings.

      That got me thinking. I know there are no rules when it comes to writing harmony, and you can do whatever you think sounds good.... but do you get Bonus Points if you keep the voicings as close as possible when changing chords?

      I think having chords that 'bounce around' can definitely work and sound good sometimes,

      but there's something extra satisfying and special about having as little movement as possible.
